entry.title: Combined summary - New BIP32 structure
entry.summary: Bitcoin developers have been discussing the improvement and standardization of Bitcoin wallet structures. One such proposal is BIP 32, which allows for a single seed to be used across different chains with separate master nodes. Another topic of discussion is the need for a compatible BIP 32 wallet structure that would enable interoperability between wallets when importing paper wallets.The agreed-upon structure includes additional levels such as "cointype" to distinguish between keys for alt coins or multisig outputs, "reserved" for miscellaneous purposes, "account" to separate different wallets within a larger wallet, and "change" to specify receiving versus change addresses. The importance of complying with BIP64 structure for wallet software and the need for scanning all possible branches to import UTXOs is highlighted in the discussions. There was debate over using a seed or master node as the starting point for serialization, and the default gap limit of 20 for users was deemed too low.In addition, there were discussions around the complexity of SPV wallets, the use of Bloom filters, and the need for a large lookahead window due to latency issues. The members also talked about the entropy size of EC pubkey, its iterations, and how it affects Bitcoin pubkeys. Developers emphasized the importance of complying with BIP64 structure for wallet software and the need to scan all possible branches to import unspent transaction outputs (UTXOs). They also acknowledged the complexity of developing secure and user-friendly software for managing cryptocurrency accounts.There are ongoing debates over whether to implement the full BIP64 or only a subset of it, with some arguing that full implementation is necessary to avoid confusion. Additionally, there are concerns about the need for subwallets and account support, with some developers arguing that multiple wallets can be created using key rotation and that subwallets can be confusing for users.In March 2014, Mike Hearn, Thomas V, and Marek collaborated to ensure compatibility of their BIP32 wallet structures. They brainstormed and came up with a new structure that is acceptable to everyone. They suggested using a hash of the word "Bitcoin", "Litecoin", or "Dogecoin" instead of building a directory of magic numbers. In an email conversation, Tamas Blummer proposed a new method for identifying cryptocurrencies by using the hash of the currency's name to avoid collisions and eliminate the need for a central directory.The email conversations also covered the creation of multiple sub-wallets and the need for a standard for sharing wallets. Discussions around BIP64 defined HD wallet structure and debated whether to store the seed or master node in the wallet structure. The thread also covers the importance of setting a gap limit for a merchant's server that is handling out hundreds of addresses.Overall, these conversations demonstrate the commitment of Bitcoin developers to improving the functionality and user experience of the technology. The ongoing evolution and development of Bitcoin as a technology is highlighted, with various stakeholders proposing changes and improvements to support different use cases and functionality. Developers emphasize the need for interoperability, backward and forward compatibility, and avoiding false expectations and dangerous assumptions.
